quiz.title: Unit 3: Demand and Supply (Quiz 1)
quiz.subtitle: 3.1 Law of Demand: Price-Quantity Relationship (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics
quiz.topic: Demand Curve, Price-Quantity Relationship, Determinants of Demand

questions.question: The law of demand states that, all other factors being equal:
options: As price increases, quantity demanded increases
As price increases, quantity demanded decreases
Price and quantity demanded have no relationship
Demand remains constant regardless of price changes
questions.explanation: The law of demand describes the inverse relationship between price and quantity demanded - when the price of a good rises, the quantity demanded falls, and vice versa.

questions.question: A demand curve typically slopes downward because:
options: Producers are willing to sell more at higher prices
Higher prices reduce consumers' purchasing power and willingness to buy
questions.explanation: The downward slope reflects both the substitution effect (consumers switch to alternatives as price rises) and income effect (higher prices reduce real purchasing power).

questions.question: Which of the following would cause a movement along the demand curve for coffee?
options: A change in the price of coffee
A change in the price of tea (a substitute)
questions.explanation: A change in the good's own price causes movement along the demand curve. Changes in other factors (income, prices of related goods, tastes) shift the entire demand curve.

questions.question: If the price of smartphones decreases from $800 to $600, what happens to quantity demanded?
questions.explanation: According to the law of demand, a price decrease leads to an increase in quantity demanded. This is movement along the demand curve, not a shift of the demand curve.

questions.question: The substitution effect occurs when:
options: Consumers buy more of a good when their income increases
Consumers switch to alternatives when a good's price rises
Producers substitute cheaper inputs when costs rise
Government substitutes one tax for another
questions.explanation: The substitution effect describes how consumers replace more expensive goods with cheaper alternatives when prices change, contributing to the law of demand.

questions.question: The income effect refers to how:
options: Price changes affect consumers' real purchasing power
Income changes affect demand for normal goods
questions.explanation: The income effect describes how price changes alter consumers' real income (purchasing power), affecting their ability to buy goods and contributing to the law of demand.

questions.question: If consumers expect prices to rise significantly in the future, current demand will:
questions.explanation: Expectations of future price increases encourage consumers to buy now rather than later, increasing current demand (shifting the demand curve to the right).

questions.question: If coffee and tea are substitutes, an increase in the price of coffee will:
questions.explanation: When the price of a substitute rises, consumers switch to the alternative, increasing demand for the substitute good (tea).

questions.question: If smartphones and data plans are complements, an increase in the price of data plans will:
questions.explanation: When the price of a complement rises, demand for both related goods decreases since they are consumed together.

questions.question: For normal goods, an increase in consumer income will:
questions.explanation: Normal goods are those for which demand increases when income rises. The demand curve shifts to the right.

questions.question: Inferior goods are characterized by:
questions.explanation: Inferior goods are those for which demand decreases when income rises, as consumers switch to higher-quality alternatives.

questions.question: A change in which factor would shift the entire demand curve for automobiles?
questions.explanation: Changes in income, tastes, prices of related goods, expectations, or number of buyers shift the entire demand curve. Changes in the good's own price cause movement along the curve.

questions.question: If the number of buyers in a market increases, the market demand curve will:
questions.explanation: More buyers means more potential purchases at each price, increasing overall demand and shifting the demand curve to the right.

questions.question: The demand schedule shows:
options: The relationship between price and quantity supplied
The relationship between price and quantity demanded
Production costs at different output levels
Consumer income at different price levels
questions.explanation: A demand schedule is a table that shows the relationship between price and quantity demanded, which can be plotted as a demand curve.

questions.question: If a successful advertising campaign increases consumer preference for a product, the demand curve will:
questions.explanation: Increased consumer preference means people are willing to buy more at each price, shifting the demand curve to the right.

questions.question: The concept of 'diminishing marginal utility' helps explain the law of demand because:
options: It shows why consumers buy more at lower prices
It demonstrates why supply curves slope upward
questions.explanation: Diminishing marginal utility means each additional unit provides less satisfaction, so consumers are only willing to buy more units at lower prices, contributing to the downward-sloping demand curve.

questions.question: If the price of movie tickets increases from $12 to $15, and quantity demanded decreases from 1,000 to 800 tickets, this demonstrates:
questions.explanation: This shows the inverse relationship between price and quantity demanded - as price rises, quantity demanded falls - illustrating the law of demand.

questions.question: A demand curve represents:
options: The maximum prices producers are willing to accept
The maximum quantities consumers are willing to buy at various prices
The minimum prices consumers are willing to pay
Production capabilities at different cost levels
questions.explanation: The demand curve shows the quantities of a good that consumers are willing and able to purchase at various prices during a specific time period.

questions.question: If consumer tastes shift away from sugary drinks toward healthier options, the demand curve for sugary drinks will:
questions.explanation: Decreased consumer preference means people are willing to buy less at each price, shifting the demand curve to the left.

questions.question: The law of demand holds true for most goods because:
options: Producers always want to sell more
Consumers have limited budgets and seek value
questions.explanation: Consumers face budget constraints and make rational choices - when prices rise, they buy less because their limited money buys fewer units, and they seek better value elsewhere.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have mastered the law of demand and understand the factors that influence consumer purchasing decisions.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand the basic concept but review the difference between movements along the demand curve versus shifts of the demand curve.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on: Law of demand = price up, quantity down; Movement along curve = price change; Shift of curve = other factors change.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember the law of demand: when price increases, quantity demanded decreases, and when price decreases, quantity demanded increases.
